awd_titl_txt: Conference: Representation Theory and Related Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a grant to support participation in the conference "Representation theory and related geometry: progress and prospects" that will take place May 27-31, 2024 at the University of Georgia in Athens, GA. This conference will bring together a diverse set of participants to discuss two key areas of mathematics and their interplay. Talks will include historical perspectives on the area as well as the latest mathematical breakthroughs. A goal of the conference is to facilitate meetings between graduate students, junior mathematicians, and seasoned experts to share knowledge and inspire new avenues of research. In addition to the formally invited talks, the conference will include opportunities for contributed talks and discussion.

The interplay of representation theory and geometry is fundamental to many of the recent breakthroughs in representation theory. Topics will include the representation theory of Lie (super)algebras, and finite, algebraic, and quantum groups; cohomological methods in representation theory; modular representation theory; geometric representation theory; categorification; tensor triangular geometry and related topics in noncommutative algebraic geometry; among others.  More specific topics of interest may include support varieties, cohomology and extensions, endotrivial modules, Schur algebras, tensor triangular geometry, and categorification. The conference website can be found at https://sites.google.com/view/representation-theory-geometry/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Grant helped to fund a conference entitled Representation theory and Related Geometry: Progress and Prospects on May 27 – 31, 2024 at the University of Georgia in Athens, GA.

The organizing committee for the conference consisted of Christopher Bendel (University of Wisconsin-Stout), Mee Seong Im (US Naval Academy), Jonathan Kujawa (University of Oklahoma), Zongzhu Lin (Kansas State University), and Laura Rider (University of Georgia). 

Our Major Outcomes were:

(1) host 20+ invited talks by a diverse set of participants, some of which were aimed at providing historical background, while others highlighted recent developments and future directions in Representation Theory.

(2) give an opportunity for presentations by junior mathematicians to share their research.

(3) highlight the deep connections within the field and avenues for future research, as well as to solidify former connections and develop new collaborations within the community of junior and senior mathematicians with Representation Theoretic interests. 

(4) encourage participation in the conference by a large, diverse group of both junior and senior mathematicians, including graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and professors.

(5) disseminate the mathematical developments discussed at the conference. 

Our Major Activities were:

(1) We had invited Plenary Talks which were 50 minutes long given by 16 participants. These included Pramod Achar, Paul Balmer, David Benson, Jon Brundan, Jon Carlson, Jie Du, Karin Erdmann, Eric Friedlander, Slava Furtorny, Shrawan Kumar, Julia Pevtsova, Cornelius Pillen, Arun Ram, Vera Serganova, Weiqiang Wang, and Milen Yakimov. We also invited another 6 early-career participants to give 30 minute talks. These included Charlotte Chan, Christopher Drupieski, Chun-Ju Lai, Paul Sobaje, Kent Vashaw, and Emilie Wiesner.

(2) We ran parallel sessions with another 45 contributed talks which were each 15 minutes in length. These participants included every career stage from graduate students and postdocs to professors. 

Other Achievements:

(1) This conference featured a broad range of topics for talks. These topics included the representation theory of Lie (super)algebras, and finite, algebraic, and quantum groups; cohomological methods in representation theory; modular representation theory; geometric representation theory; categorification; tensor triangular geometry and related topics in noncommutative algebraic geometry; among many others.

(2) Conference schedule facilitated many interactions. We included several 30 minute coffee breaks to allow mathematical discussions. Optional group social activities on Wednesday afternoon were organized by local organizers. These included an a long hike, a short hike, a visit to the Georgia Museum of Art. We also had several classrooms reserved for Wednesday and Friday afternoon in case participants or collaborators wanted to meet for small group discussion. There was also a Conference Reception Thursday evening to encourage even more interaction among participants in different career stages. 

(3) We implemented a number of steps to attract a diverse audience of graduate students and junior researchers, in particular, of women and members of underrepresented groups. 

A conference website was created and a conference poster. The poster and web link were shared with colleagues, collaborators, and universities (and affiliated listservs) with strong representation theory and geometry presence.

The conference was also advertised via the following means:

  • FDLIST run by Matthew Pressland at the Bielefeld University.
  • The Southeast Lie theory workshop in 2023 and that event’s email list.
  • The email list of USTARS (underrepresented students in topology and algebra research symposium).
  • The Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) website and email list.
  • The Women and Mathematics (WAM) group at the Institute for Advanced Study (IAS) representation theory and geometry conference email lists.
  • The Women in Noncommutative Algebra and Representation Theory (WINART) email list.
  • The Women in Algebra and Combinatorics email list (facilitated by Christian Lenart at SUNY Albany).
  • Instantons and Foams email list, from a workshop held at MIT.
  • Knots in Washington email list, semiannual conference held at the George Washington University.
  • To over 74 members of the University of Georgia Algebra Group on Facebook.
  • To over 131 members of Representation Theory Facebook group.
  • On some of the organizers’ professional websites.

Our advertising generated significant interest in the conference. Indeed, we had at least 141 participants attend the conference. 

Results from the conference have been disseminated to communities of interest by the following means:

(1) A conference webpage can be found at https://sites.google.com/view/representation-theory-geometry/home. 

(2) That webpage has abstracts for all talks. 

(3) It also includes a link to a google drive with slides from the 55 talks. Each of those particpants gave permission to share their slides in this way.

(4) Furthermore, it includes a link to a youtube playlist with recordings of 23 of the conference talks. Again, these were talks by particpants who agreed to have their talk recorded and shared in this way.  

(5) Finally, the conference organizers are also developing a conference proceedings where many of the mathematical ideas discussed at the meeting may be formally published. This is in progress at this time.
